item.title: Investing in corporate bonds will be made more accessible for Singaporean investors
item.description: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has launched two new regulations aimed at making it easier for retail investors – individuals who purchase securities for personal investment purposes – to participate in corporate bond offerings. These changes are part of MAS’s broader strategy to expand retail investors’ investment choices by providing access to simpler, lower-risk investment products. Corporate issuers typically rely on the wholesale bond market for funding due to the higher expenses associated with reaching retail investors.

item.title: ERGA and the Audiovisual and Media Services Directive 2.0: A European Regulators Group without Borders?
item.description: Professor Lorna Woods, University of Essex In 2014, the European Commission created ERGA to help implement the Audiovisual Media Services Directive (AVMSD) and support a unified European market. This built upon the existing High Level Group of Regulatory Authorities, established in 2003, which brought national enforcement bodies together twice a year. The goal was to improve collaboration between these authorities to ensure the AVMSD was applied consistently across Europe. This reflects a broader EU trend of forming networks, sometimes including member states, to promote harmonization.

item.title: Proposed changes to the tenure of independent board directors in Singapore
item.description: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) is asking for public opinion on its suggestion to implement a strict nine-year limit for independent board directors (IDs) and end the two-tier voting system for long-serving IDs. The consultation document states that if directors wish to stay on after the limit, they must be reclassified as non-independent, even if their appointment was previously approved by a two-tier vote. They are also seeking feedback on making it mandatory for companies to disclose the exact amount and breakdown of board directors’ and the CEO’s pay in their annual report, identifying them by name.
